questions.question_text: Which of the following commands is used to clear the KV store?

discussion.content: Answer is A: Replicated copies of non-searchable data are smaller than copies of searchable data, because they include only the data and not the associated index files. Increase search factor for searchable data

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/latest/Indexer/Thesearchfactor#Search_factor

another question with too little context, as A depends on B and A and B depend on C.
If your search factor is already at replication factor (e.g. sf=3, rf=3) you would need to increase both and if your sf equals the current count of your search heads, you would need to increase their count as well.
Assuming that's not the case the answer can only be A) as that's required in all cases.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A, why does it say B? That will only increase non searchable copies

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Answer: A

Selected Answer: A
A is the one

Selected Answer: A

Selected Answer: A
Only increasing the search factor with effect searchable data. increasing the replication factor will not effect the searchable data because it replicates non-searchable data.
A is the correct Answer
I believe the answer should be A

choices.D: Increasing the number of CPUs on the indexers in the cluster.
choices.B: Increasing the replication factor in the cluster.
choices.C: Increasing the number of search heads in the cluster.
choices.A: Increasing the search factor in the cluster.

questions.question_text: Stakeholders have identified high availability for searchable data as their top priority. Which of the following best addresses this requirement?

Indexing is slow and real-time search results are delayed in a Splunk environment with two indexers and one search head. There is ample CPU and memory available on the indexers. Which of the following is most likely to improve indexing performance?

choices.D: Decrease the maximum concurrent scheduled searches in limits.conf
choices.C: Decrease the maximum size of the search pipelines in limits.conf
choices.B: Increase the number of parallel ingestion pipelines in server.conf
choices.A: Increase the maximum number of hot buckets in indexes.conf

discussion.content: Should be B

Selected Answer: B
B is correct answer
I went with D as the parallelization features are intended for customers with excess CPU cores and I/O capacity to leverage their hardware for improved performance across the indexing tier.

comments.content: key part is indexing is slow

discussion.content: Parallel ingestion increases performance https://conf.splunk.com/files/2016/slides/harnessing-performance-and-scalability-with-parallelization.pdf
B is correct

questions.question_text: A three-node search head cluster is skipping a large number of searches across time. What should be done to increase scheduled search capacity on the search head cluster?

discussion.content: correct is B: cluster-admin -145

Selected Answer: B
I'd say B because the question makes a point to emphasize a cluster. They'd have no reason to specify the cluster if the answer was D

Selected Answer: D
Could be Answer D.
Ref: https://lantern.splunk.com/Splunk_Platform/Product_Tips/Searching_and_Reporting/Reducing_skipped_searches#:~:text=The%20total%20maximum%20concurrency%20limit%20is%20too%20low

comments.content:
Jacking up the max_searches_per_cpu doesn't always solve the problem. There a limit to this strategy. Once you're out of cpu, its going to have large queue and skipped searches. 

My answer would be B or ensure your scheduled reports are scheduled for exact same time.

discussion.content:
D 
Overall search quota. This quota determines the maximum number of historical searches (combined scheduled and ad hoc) that the cluster can run concurrently. This quota is configured with max_searches_per_cpu and related settings in limits.conf

https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.2.4/DistSearch/SHCjobscheduling

Selected Answer: B
A three-node search head cluster is skipping a large
Should be D: https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.2.4/DistSearch/SHCjobscheduling

comments.content: If you switch the captain_is_adhoc_searchhead to true, it will stop all the scheduled searches on the captain SH. So, D is better answer

discussion.content:
Answer is C i guess.
The SHC is over-tasked with too many scheduled searches, resulting in a high skip ratio
